scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded by acknowledging the difficulty and suggesting to prioritize tasks and see if additional resources are needed. As the team begins to break down the tasks, [Monica] seems hesitant and [Bob] looks frustrated. You advised the team to stay focused on what they can control, and suggested taking a short break before tackling the tasks one step at a time. [Monica] and [Bob] still seem uneasy.
scenes.description: [Monica] shakes her head and says: 'Even with a break, I still feel like we're drowning in work.' [Bob] sighs and adds: 'Yeah, a break won't change the fact that we're overloaded and understaffed.'

options.text: I understand it's tough, but let's focus on what we can achieve in the next hour.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's feelings while encouraging short-term focus, showing good interpersonal balance and social skills.

options.text: I hear you. Maybe we need to escalate this to management and ask for more support.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the concerns and proposed a practical solution, showing good emotional perception and communication skills.

options.text: I get it. If anyone has a better idea, now's the time to speak up. Otherwise, we stick to the plan.
options.analysis: You invited alternative suggestions, showing good communication skills, but emotional perception and interpersonal balance could be improved.
